[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: TryClearContractProposingData()] [State Leak] Can an attacker cause memory/storage leaks by creating proposals that never reach CodeChecked status, leaving entries in ContractProposingInputMap forever? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: ProposeNewContract()] [Reentrancy] Can an attacker exploit Context.SendInline to the authorization contract to reenter ProposeNewContract before the first call completes, creating duplicate proposals with the same proposedContractInputHash? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: ReleaseApprovedContract()] [Reentrancy] Can an attacker reenter through Context.SendInline to the authorization contract's Release method, manipulating contractProposingInput.Status multiple times before the transaction completes? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: ValidateProposerAuthority()] [False Positive] Can an attacker deploy a malicious authorization contract that returns true for ValidateProposerInWhiteList for any address, bypassing proposer authorization checks? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: DeploySystemSmartContract()] [Inline Call Exploitation] Can an attacker include malicious transactions in the TransactionMethodCallList that get executed via Context.SendInline after deployment, exploiting the newly deployed contract's uninitialized state? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: SetMethodFee()] [Fee Manipulation] Can an attacker who controls MethodFeeController.OwnerAddress set method fees to 0 for all critical functions, enabling free spam attacks on the contract? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: SetMethodFee()] [Fee Manipulation] Can an attacker set method fees to maximum int64 value, effectively preventing anyone from calling those methods due to prohibitive costs? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: ChangeMethodFeeController()] [Privilege Escalation] Can an attacker change MethodFeeController to an organization they control, then set fees to manipulate contract economics or block legitimate usage? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: GetMethodFee()] [Special Case Bypass] Can an attacker exploit the special case for ReleaseApprovedUserSmartContract where IsSizeFeeFree is true to perform unbounded operations without paying size fees? (Medium)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: RequiredMethodFeeControllerSet()] [Initialization Race] Can an attacker front-run the first call requiring MethodFeeController to set it to a malicious Parliament organization address before the legitimate initialization? [File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: GetContractAddressByName()] [Name Squatting] Can an attacker deploy a malicious contract with a name hash that collides with or resembles a system contract name, tricking users into interacting with the wrong contract? (High)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: ValidateSystemContractAddress()] [Fake System Contract] Can an attacker bypass system contract validation by registering a malicious contract with a name hash that matches a legitimate system contract's hash? (Critical)

[File: contract/AElf.Contracts.Genesis/BasicContractZero.cs] [Function: GetSigner()] [Privacy Leak] Can an attacker discover signer relationships between addresses by querying GetSigner for all known addresses, revealing off-chain identity connections? (Low)
